Description: The 16th National Congress of the CPC was held on November 8-14, 2002 in Beijing. The Congress marked the transition of power between Jiang Zemin and Hu Jintao.
The 18th National Congress of the Communist Party of China began on November 8, 2012 in Beijing, China. The Congress marked the transition of power between  Hu Jintao and Xi Jingping
The APEC China 2014 was the 22nd annual gathering of APEC leaders. It was held in Beijing from 10–12, November 2014.
The Arab Spring was a series of anti-government protests, uprisings and armed rebellions that spread across the Middle East in early 2011.
The 2008 summer olympic games took place in Beijing, China, from 8 to 24 August 2008
Following  the June 2012 publication of a story revealing the family fortune of Xi Jinping Bloomberg was blocked in China.
Keyword Examples:
彭博在中国被屏蔽
(Bloomberg is blocked in China)

Description: Bo Xilai is a former Chinese politician. He came to prominence through his tenures as the mayor of the coastal economic hub of Dalian and then governor of Liaoning province. On 22 September 2013, Bo was found guilty of corruption, stripped of all his assets, and sentenced to life imprisonment
Keyword Examples: 薄熙来倒了 下一个周永康 (Bo Xilai has fallen -- Zhou Yongkang is next)

Description: In April 2008, after the 2008 Olympic torch relay was disrupted by Tibetan independence advocates in London and especially Paris, Pro-government activists in China promoted boycotting Carrefour because of its French roots
References to National Day of the People's Republic of China, a public holiday in the People's Republic of China celebrated annually on October 1
Reference to arrests of members of the Eastern Lighting "dooms day" cult in China
Keyword Examples: 大红龙 福音 (Red Dragon Gospel)

Description: On May 16 1966, a notification was published by the Communist Party of China (CPC) that described Mao's ideological justification for the Cultural Revolution. Opinions over the legacy of the revolution remain divided.
Keyword Examples:
反思文革
(Reflections on Cultural Revolution)

Description: Dai Jianyong (also known as 麻痹哥, "paralysis brother") is a Shanghai artist who was detained by Chinese police for “picking quarrels and provoking trouble" after he produced a satirical image of President Xi Jinping.

The Senkaku Islands dispute, or Diaoyu Islands dispute, concerns a territorial dispute over a group of uninhabited islands known as the Senkaku Islands in Japan, the Diaoyu Islands in the People's Republic of China (PRC),and Tiaoyutai Islands in the Republic of China (ROC or Taiwan)

Ezubao (E租宝), was a peer-to-peer financial platform based in the eastern Chinese province of Anhui that took in more than 50 billion yuan from 900,000 investors before it came under investigation in December 2015. It was subsequently shut down and 21 people involved with the scheme were arrested.

In March 2012, there was a fatal car crash involving a Ferrari, that was driven by the son of party official close to President Hu Jintao. Within hours of the crash, photos were deleted off the Internet and searches of "Ferrari" were blocked.
Keyword Examples: 北京 法拉利车祸 (Beijing Ferrari car accident)

Description: Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 (MH370/MAS370)was a scheduled international passenger flight operated by Malaysia Airlines that disappeared on 8 March 2014 while flying from Kuala Lumpur International Airport, Malaysia, to Beijing Capital International Airport in China.
References to forced demolitions and illegal land seizures and land grabs in urban and rural parts of China.

The 11th meeting of the G20 was held from September 4 to 5 2016 in Hangzhou. In President Xi Jinping’s opening speech he made a gaffe accidentally saying “reduce taxes and make roads easy [to travel on], facilitate commerce, and loosen clothing” (轻关易道，通商宽衣) when he should have said “reduce taxes and make roads easy [to travel on], facilitate commerce and be lenient to farmers” (轻关易道，通商宽农)
Keyword Examples:
通商寬yi
(Facilitate Commerce and Loosen Clothing)

Description: On January 12, 2010, Google announced that it was "no longer willing to continue censoring" results on Google.cn, citing a breach of Gmail accounts of Chinese human rights activists.

Lam Wing-kee, one of five Hong Kong booksellers who went missing in 2015 and turned up in mainland custody revealed details of his detention at a press conference in Hong Kong on June 16, 2016. Lam said that he had been put through eight months of mental torture and was forced to provide a televised confession.

On Feburary 29 2016, three localist political Hong Kong groups, Civic Passion, Hong Kong Resurgence Order and Proletariat Political Institute announced plans for the September 2016 Legislative Council Election.

In May 2011 protests broke out in Xiwuqi, Inner Mongolia. Protests arose after the death of Mr. Morigen (Mergen), a Mongolian herder who was killed by a Han truck driver. Chinese officials order clampdowns and censorship.

A popular online travel show, On The Road (侣行) was banned in China after an episode in which the hosts visited Kurdish fighters in northern Iraq and flew a drone over ISIS filming military positions in neighbouring Syria. The hosts claimed the footage was shared with the French Air Force who used it to target bombing raids. Media reports claim the show may have been banned over concern that it could incite retaliation from ISIS.

2011 Chinese pro-democracy protests, also known as the Chinese Jasmine Revolution refer to public assemblies in over a dozen cities in China starting on 20 February 2011, inspired by and named after the Jasmine Revolution in Tunisia.
Reference to rumours of Jiang Zemin, China's former President, being critically ill and dying
May 2013 event when women fell from building, police ruled suicide, family organized thousands in march to ask for investigation
Keyword Examples: 袁利亚离奇死亡 (Yuan Liya died mysteriously)

Description: In February 2012, riots broke out in the City of Kashgar, in Xinjiang, China killing 12 people
In the evening of March 1, 2014, a knife attack occurred inside the Kunming Railway Station in Kunming, Yunnan, China.
Keyword Examples: 如果新疆的恐怖分子不是砍昆明

Description: In May 2016, news reports circulated that Miao Deshun, a man believed to be the last person still in prison for participating in the 1989 Tiananmen protests is scheduled to be released in October, 2016. He was convicted of arson for throwing a basket onto a burning tank and was sentenced to death with a two-year reprieve in August 1989.
References to Occupy Central and the Umbrella movement
Keyword Examples:
大学生罢课
(Students go on strike)

Description: Occupy movement is an international socio-political movement against social inequality and lack of "real democracy" around the world, its primary goal being to advance social and economic justice and new forms of democracy.
In 2012, reports of high oil prices were suspected to cause social instability.
Keyword Examples: 油价 占领 (Oil price occupy)

Description: Popular online streaming sites abruptly cancelled plans to live broadcast the 88th Academy Awards on the eve of the Oscars night in China. Broadcasting of the awards were taken over 1905.com (run by a state agency), which aired it with a 15 second delay. Speculations attribute the cancellation to sensitivities over one of the nominees for Best Documentary Feature, “Winter on Fire”, a film on the Euromaidan protests in Ukraine
Keyword Examples:
凛冬烈火
Winter on fire

Description: The Scarborough Shoal standoff refers to tensions between China (PRC) and the Philippines which began on April 8, 2012 over the Philippine Navy apprehension of eight mainland Chinese fishing vessels in the disputed Scarborough Shoal.

The 2008 Sichuan earthquake occurred at 02:28:01 PM China Standard Time on May 12, 2008. measuring at 8.0 Ms,] the earthquake's epicenter was located 80 kilometres (50 mi) west-northwest of Chengdu, the provincial capital, with a focal depth of 19 km (12 mi).
Keyword Examples: 不能说的真话 (Truth that cannot be spoken)

Description: In a case known as the South China Sea Arbitration, the Philippines under provisions of the United Nations Conventions on the Law of the Sea brought complaints against China over territorial claims in the South China Sea. On July 12, 2016, an international tribunal in the Hague ruled in favour of the Philippines and concluded that China has no legal basis to claim historical rights in the South China Sea. China rejected the ruling.
Keyword Examples:
南海仲裁
South China Sea Arbitration

Description: There are a number of incidents involving South Korea and China confrontations in the yellow sea. In 2011 a South Korean coast guard was killed while trying to seize a Chinese fishing boat. In 2012 a Chinese fisherman was killed following confrontation with South Korean coast guard. In 2014 a Chinese was also killed during a raid of his vessel by South Korean coastguards.
Keyword Examples:
中国驻韩大使馆
(Chinese Embassy in Seoul)

Description: Southern Chinese province Guangdong’s official broadcaster guangdong TV was reported to plan to quietly switch most of its programming from Cantonese to Mandarin on September 1, 2015. The news sparked a round of criticism among Cantonese speakers in Guangzhou city. The “Hold Up Cantonese Movement” (撑粤语/chēng yuèyǔ) initially started in July 2010 when the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference Guangzhou Committee proposed increasing Mandarin programming on Guangzhou Television’s main and news channels. As Hong Kong is also a Cantonese-speaking city, some has also linked preserving the language to preserving “Hong Kong identities”.

References to the 2008 Chinese milk scandal, a food safety incident in the People's Republic of China, involving milk and infant formula, and other food materials and components, adulterated with melamine.

In June 2016, over 20,000 residents in San Francisco signed a petition to show support for the Tian Guo Marching Band of Western America, a Falun Gong-related organization. On April 17, 2016, a parade by the group was canceled right before it was to being because “content on the parade banner does not match that on the parade application.”
Keyword Examples:
天國樂團
(Tian Guo Marching Band)

Description: A series of explosions in a container storage station at the Port of Tianjin killed 173 people and injured hundreds of others. Reporting on the event was heavily restricted by Chinese authorities particularly rumors and comments critical of how the government handled the incident.
Keyword Examples:
天津核爆炸
(Explosions in Tianjin were nuclear)

Description: The Tiananmen Square protests were student-led demonstrations in Beijing in 1989. The protests were forcibly suppressed after the government declared martial law. In what became widely known as the Tiananmen Square Massacre, troops with assault rifles and tanks killed at least several hundred demonstrators trying to block the military's advance towards Tiananmen Square.
Self-immolations are a controversial form of protest that Tibetans have used as a statement of opposition to Chinese government practices concerning Tibet
The July 2009 Ürümqi riots were a series of violent riots over several days that broke out on 5 July 2009 in Ürümqi, the capital city of the Xinjiang, China
Keyword Examples:
乌鲁木齐血债血偿
(Urumqi, blood for blood)

Description: On July 23, 2011, two high-speed trains travelling on the Yongtaiwen railway line collided on a viaduct in the suburbs of Wenzhou, Zhejiang province, China.
Keyword Examples: 张副总 动车 (Vice Premier Zhang -- train)

Description: Wukan is a fishing village in southern Guangdong that has earned renown for activism. In 2016, villagers took to the streets calling for the a detained democratically-elected local leader and party secretary Lin Zulian and the resolution of a long-simmering dispute over land sales.
A performer on YY.com caused a scandal on social media when she accidentally livestreamed herself having sex on the platform.

On June 11 2015 as part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign, Zhou Yongkang, who was once one of China's most powerful political figures, was sentenced to life in prison on corruption charges.
Keyword Examples:
一审被判无期
(Sentenced to life in prison in the first tria)l

Description: Names of specific companies
Words or terms for which the context, meaning or relevance can not be determined.
General terms that refer to business practices that are too general to fit in any other category.
Names without clear context or match to an Individual
Names of CPC members / government officials

Names of dissidents / activists. These terms are not always synonymous. For example, a rights defender advocating for land rights may not be politically against the CPC (as a political dissident would be). However, for now, these will be grouped together as they are often the targets of government harassment.
Names of relatives and associates of prominent government officials.
Keyword Examples:
习夫人
 (Wife of Xi [Jinping] aka Peng Liyuan)

Description: Victims  / perpetrators of crimes (e.g. murder, rape, etc)
China has strict regulations on the publishing industry and that is why many dissent writers have resorted to Hong Kong and Taiwan to publish on “sensitive” topics.
Keyword Examples: “黄祸”, Yellow Peril written by Wang Lixiong

Description: Explicit references to Great Fire Wall, Internet filtering in China, and censorship of other media / content.
Keyword Examples: 河蟹社会 (river crab society / harmonious society)

Description: References to Charter 08, a manifesto initially signed by over 350 Chinese intellectuals and human rights activists
General terms referring to China, Chinese culture, or the Chinese people that are too generic to fit in any other category.
General References to Christian practice in China including: Chinese pastors, House churches, etc
Keyword Examples:
你们要向耶和华唱新歌
(Sing to the Lord a new song)

Description: Church of Almighty God is a Chinese Christian movement that has been described by the government as a cult and terrorist group.
References to general terms related to Internet censorship circumvention or circumvention software.
Pejorative, derogatory terms referring to CPC, terms referencing criticism of CPC
General references to the CPC including government departments, buildings, CPC doctrine, etc
Terms that reference corruption scandals involving either government of private sector actors. (e.g. embezzlement, bribery, etc.)
General references to criminal detentions, re-education through labor, imprisonment, black jails, etc.
General references to Democracy Movements in China
General health references and references to specific diseases  (e.g. Aids, SARS, Ebola, etc.)
General references to ethnic groups in China
Keyword Examples: 民族平等、文字平等、保护母语 (Ethnic equality, language equality, protection of the mother tongue)

Description: Falun Gong is a relgious movement in China that has been persecuted by the government
General terms referencing government and political systems. Not related to any particular country / jurisdiction
References to Hong Kong

Chinese authorities accuse Wu Zeheng, the head of the Buddhist-inspired Hua Zang Dharma, of using his holy status to defraud and have sex with devotees. This proscecution has been called politically motivated.
General references to the Hui ethnic group in China.
General reference to human rights with no direct reference to particular event, group or person.
Reference to specific  Human rights organizations
General references to Chinese and Japanese relations
General references to the United States and US politicians
References to Islam and muslim culture
General references to the law and legal terms.
Generic terms related to the media
References to specific independent / opposition media in China
Keyword Examples: 苹果日报香港版 (Apple Daily Hong Kong Edition)

Description: References to specific pro government media in China (e.g, People's Daily, CCTV, Global Times, etc.)
Reference to specfic international media
Keyword Examples: 自由亚洲电台 (Radio Free Asia)

Description: Used for content relating to the Chinese military or police.
General references to national security
Keyword Examples: 危及国家安全 (Threat to national security)

Description: General terms related to protests, demonstrations, marches including those that are not related to a particular event.
Petitioning is an administrative system in the PRC to hear complaints and grievances from individual citizens.
Political Parties related to China that are not CPC
Keyword Examples: 中国自由民主党 (Liberty Democracy Party of China)

Description: General references to religion that do not appear directly related to particular religion or issue.
References to Taiwan
References to terrorism (groups, ideologies, persons)
General references to Tibet, Tibetan culture, issues, etc rather than specific incidents (i.e. self immolation)
Encouragement and publicization of Communist Party officials who have left the party, including events and media, primarily organized by Falun Gong-related media.
Terms that generally refer to Uyghur related issues rather than specific events (i.e. Urumqi Riots July 2009)
References to gambling (websites, services, casinos, etc)

Illicit products and materials - e.g. narcotics, firearms, explosives, weapons, poison, counterfeit goods, exam takers. Some products included here are not illegal but there are concerns about the use of the products in crimes. For example realistic human face masks, air guns, etc
Chinese lottery and incidents and scams related to it
References to sexuality, pornography, prostituion, etc.
References to online novels or novels which have versions that can be found online.
References to names of Chinese software products and websites
Code snippets including: malicious code, messages from software, or official-looking administrative messages from service
Keywords that are obviously emails
General technology terms
References to devices and other hardware
References to online games
Entries that are obviously  phone numbers
Internal references to Sina UC / Show app strings / operations. Keywords related to the company generally should go in "Business"
References to commercial off the shelf spyware / malware
URLs or URL fragments.
User names, id numbers, QQ accounts, and phone numbers
